013package org.apache.juneau;
014
015import static org.apache.juneau.collections.JsonMap.*;
016import java.beans.*;
017import java.io.*;
018import java.lang.annotation.*;
019import java.lang.reflect.*;
020import java.util.*;
021import java.util.function.*;
022
023import org.apache.juneau.annotation.*;
024import org.apache.juneau.collections.*;
025import org.apache.juneau.internal.*;
026import org.apache.juneau.swap.*;
027import org.apache.juneau.utils.*;
028
029/**
030 * Context class for classes that use {@link BeanContext} objects.
031 *
032 * <p>
033 * This abstraction exists to allow different kinds of subclasses (e.g. JsonSerilalizer, XmlParser...) to share bean context objects since
034 * bean context objects are heavyweight objects that cache metadata about encountered beans.
035 *
036 * <ul class='notes'>
037 *    <li class='note'>This class is thread safe and reusable.
038 * </ul>
039 *
040 * <ul class='seealso'>
041 * </ul>
042 */
043public abstract class BeanContextable extends Context {
044
045   //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
046   // Builder
047   //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
048
049   /**
050    * Builder class.
051    */
052   @FluentSetters(ignore={"annotations","debug"})
053   public abstract static class Builder extends Context.Builder {
054
055      BeanContext.Builder bcBuilder;
056      BeanContext bc;
057
058      /**
059       * Constructor.
060       *
061       * All default settings.
062       */
063      protected Builder() {
064         super();
065         this.bcBuilder = BeanContext.create();
066         registerBuilders(bcBuilder);
067      }
068
069      /**
070       * Copy constructor.
071       *
072       * @param copyFrom The bean to copy from.
073       */
074      protected Builder(BeanContextable copyFrom) {
075         super(copyFrom);
076         this.bcBuilder = copyFrom.getBeanContext().copy();
077         registerBuilders(bcBuilder);
078      }
079
080      /**
081       * Copy constructor.
082       *
083       * @param copyFrom The builder to copy from.
084       */
085      protected Builder(Builder copyFrom) {
086         super(copyFrom);
087         this.bcBuilder = copyFrom.bcBuilder.copy();
088         this.bc = copyFrom.bc;
089         registerBuilders(bcBuilder);
090      }
091
092      @Override /* Context.Builder */
093      public abstract Builder copy();
094
095      @Override /* Context.Builder */
096      public HashKey hashKey() {
097         return HashKey.of(
098            super.hashKey(),
099            bcBuilder.hashKey(),
100            bc == null ? 0 : bc.hashKey
101         );
102      }
103
104      /**
105       * Returns the inner bean context builder.
106       *
107       * @return The inner bean context builder.
108       */
109      public BeanContext.Builder beanContext() {
110         return bcBuilder;
111      }
112
113      /**
114       * Applies an operation to the inner bean context builder.
115       *
116       * @param operation The operation to apply.
117       * @return This object.
118       */
119      public final Builder beanContext(Consumer<BeanContext.Builder> operation) {
120         operation.accept(beanContext());
121         return this;
122      }
123
124      //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
125      // Properties
126      //-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
127
128      /**
129       * Overrides the bean context builder.
130       *
131       * <p>
132       * Used when sharing bean context builders across multiple context objects.
133       * For example, {@link org.apache.juneau.jsonschema.JsonSchemaGenerator.Builder} uses this to apply common bean settings with the JSON
134       * serializer and parser.
135       *
136       * @param value The new value for this setting.
137       * @return This object.
138       */
139      @FluentSetter
140      public Builder beanContext(BeanContext.Builder value) {
141         this.bcBuilder = value;
142         return this;
143      }
144
145      /**
146       * Specifies an already-instantiated bean context to use.
147       *
148       * <p>
149       * Provides an optimization for cases where serializers and parsers can use an existing
150       * bean context without having to go through <c><jv>beanContext</jv>.copy().build()</c>.
151       * An example is {@link BeanContext#getBeanToStringSerializer()}.
152       *
153       * @param value The bean context to use.
154       * @return This object.
155       */
156      @FluentSetter
157      public Builder beanContext(BeanContext value) {
158         this.bc = value;
159         return this;
160      }
161
162      /**
163       * Minimum bean class visibility.
164       *
165       * <p>
166       * Classes are not considered beans unless they meet the minimum visibility requirements.
167       * For example, if the visibility is <jsf>PUBLIC</jsf> and the bean class is <jk>protected</jk>, then the class
168       * will not be interpreted as a bean class and be serialized as a string.
169       * Use this setting to reduce the visibility requirement.
170       *
171       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
172       * <p class='bjava'>
173       *    <jc>// A bean with a protected class and one field.</jc>
174       *    <jk>protected class</jk> MyBean {
175       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>;
176       *    }
177       *
178       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that's capable of serializing the class.</jc>
179       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
180       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
181       *       .beanClassVisibility(<jsf>PROTECTED</jsf>)
182       *       .build();
183       *
184       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo","bar"}</jc>
185       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
186       * </p>
187       *
188       * <ul class='notes'>
189       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Bean @Bean} annotation can be used on a non-public bean class to override this setting.
190       *    <li class='note'>The {@link BeanIgnore @BeanIgnore} annotation can also be used on a public bean class to ignore it as a bean.
191       * </ul>
192       *
193       * <ul class='seealso'>
194       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#beanClassVisibility()}
195       * </ul>
196       *
197       * @param value
198       *    The new value for this setting.
199       *    <br>The default is {@link Visibility#PUBLIC}.
200       * @return This object.
201       */
202      @FluentSetter
203      public Builder beanClassVisibility(Visibility value) {
204         bcBuilder.beanClassVisibility(value);
205         return this;
206      }
207
208      /**
209       * Minimum bean constructor visibility.
210       *
211       * <p>
212       * Only look for constructors with the specified minimum visibility.
213       *
214       * <p>
215       * This setting affects the logic for finding no-arg constructors for bean.  Normally, only <jk>public</jk> no-arg
216       * constructors are used.  Use this setting if you want to reduce the visibility requirement.
217       *
218       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
219       * <p class='bjava'>
220       *    <jc>// A bean with a protected constructor and one field.</jc>
221       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
222       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf>;
223       *
224       *       <jk>protected</jk> MyBean() {}
225       *    }
226       *
227       *    <jc>// Create a parser capable of calling the protected constructor.</jc>
228       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = ReaderParser
229       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
230       *       .beanConstructorVisibility(<jsf>PROTECTED</jsf>)
231       *       .build();
232       *
233       *    <jc>// Use it.</jc>
234       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'bar'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
235       * </p>
236       *
237       * <ul class='notes'>
238       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Beanc @Beanc} annotation can also be used to expose a non-public constructor.
239       *    <li class='note'>The {@link BeanIgnore @BeanIgnore} annotation can also be used on a public bean constructor to ignore it.
240       * </ul>
241       *
242       * <ul class='seealso'>
243       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#beanConstructorVisibility()}
244       * </ul>
245       *
246       * @param value
247       *    The new value for this setting.
248       *    <br>The default is {@link Visibility#PUBLIC}.
249       * @return This object.
250       */
251      @FluentSetter
252      public Builder beanConstructorVisibility(Visibility value) {
253         bcBuilder.beanConstructorVisibility(value);
254         return this;
255      }
256
257      /**
258       * Minimum bean field visibility.
259       *
260       * <p>
261       * Only look for bean fields with the specified minimum visibility.
262       *
263       * <p>
264       * This affects which fields on a bean class are considered bean properties.  Normally only <jk>public</jk> fields are considered.
265       * Use this setting if you want to reduce the visibility requirement.
266       *
267       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
268       * <p class='bjava'>
269       *    <jc>// A bean with a protected field.</jc>
270       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
271       *       <jk>protected</jk> String <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>;
272       *    }
273       *
274       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that recognizes the protected field.</jc>
275       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
276       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
277       *       .beanFieldVisibility(<jsf>PROTECTED</jsf>)
278       *       .build();
279       *
280       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"bar"}</jc>
281       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
282       * </p>
283       *
284       * <p>
285       * Bean fields can be ignored as properties entirely by setting the value to {@link Visibility#NONE}
286       *
287       * <p class='bjava'>
288       *    <jc>// Disable using fields as properties entirely.</jc>
289       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
290       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
291       *       .beanFieldVisibility(<jsf>NONE</jsf>)
292       *       .build();
293       * </p>
294       *
295       * <ul class='notes'>
296       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Beanp @Beanp} annotation can also be used to expose a non-public field.
297       *    <li class='note'>The {@link BeanIgnore @BeanIgnore} annotation can also be used on a public bean field to ignore it as a bean property.
298       * </ul>
299       *
300       * <ul class='seealso'>
301       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#beanFieldVisibility()}
302       * </ul>
303       *
304       * @param value
305       *    The new value for this setting.
306       *    <br>The default is {@link Visibility#PUBLIC}.
307       * @return This object.
308       */
309      @FluentSetter
310      public Builder beanFieldVisibility(Visibility value) {
311         bcBuilder.beanFieldVisibility(value);
312         return this;
313      }
314
315      /**
316       * Bean interceptor.
317       *
318       * <p>
319       * Bean interceptors can be used to intercept calls to getters and setters and alter their values in transit.
320       *
321       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
322       * <p class='bjava'>
323       *    <jc>// Interceptor that strips out sensitive information.</jc>
324       *    <jk>public class</jk> AddressInterceptor <jk>extends</jk> BeanInterceptor&lt;Address&gt; {
325       *
326       *       <jk>public</jk> Object readProperty(Address <jv>bean</jv>, String <jv>name</jv>, Object <jv>value</jv>) {
327       *          <jk>if</jk> (<js>"taxInfo"</js>.equals(<jv>name</jv>))
328       *             <jk>return</jk> <js>"redacted"</js>;
329       *          <jk>return</jk> <jv>value</jv>;
330       *       }
331       *
332       *       <jk>public</jk> Object writeProperty(Address <jv>bean</jv>, String <jv>name</jv>, Object <jv>value</jv>) {
333       *          <jk>if</jk> (<js>"taxInfo"</js>.equals(<jv>name</jv>) &amp;&amp; <js>"redacted"</js>.equals(<jv>value</jv>))
334       *             <jk>return</jk> TaxInfoUtils.<jsm>lookup</jsm>(<jv>bean</jv>.getStreet(), <jv>bean</jv>.getCity(), <jv>bean</jv>.getState());
335       *          <jk>return</jk> <jv>value</jv>;
336       *       }
337       *    }
338       *
339       *    <jc>// Our bean class.</jc>
340       *    <jk>public class</jk> Address {
341       *       <jk>public</jk> String getTaxInfo() {...}
342       *       <jk>public void</jk> setTaxInfo(String <jv>value</jv>) {...}
343       *    }
344       *
345       *    <jc>// Register filter on serializer or parser.</jc>
346       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
347       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
348       *       .beanInterceptor(Address.<jk>class</jk>, AddressInterceptor.<jk>class</jk>)
349       *       .build();
350       *
351       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"taxInfo":"redacted"}</jc>
352       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> Address());
353       * </p>
354       *
355       * <ul class='seealso'>
356       *    <li class='jc'>{@link BeanInterceptor}
357       *    <li class='ja'>{@link Bean#interceptor() Bean(interceptor)}
358       * </ul>
359       *
360       * @param on The bean that the filter applies to.
361       * @param value
362       *    The new value for this setting.
363       * @return This object.
364       */
365      @FluentSetter
366      public Builder beanInterceptor(Class<?> on, Class<? extends BeanInterceptor<?>> value) {
367         bcBuilder.beanInterceptor(on, value);
368         return this;
369      }
370
371      /**
372       * BeanMap.put() returns old property value.
373       *
374       * <p>
375       * When enabled, then the {@link BeanMap#put(String,Object) BeanMap.put()} method will return old property
376       * values.  Otherwise, it returns <jk>null</jk>.
377       *
378       * <p>
379       * Disabled by default because it introduces a slight performance penalty during serialization.
380       *
381       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
382       * <p class='bjava'>
383       *    <jc>// Create a context that creates BeanMaps with normal put() behavior.</jc>
384       *    BeanContext <jv>context</jv> = BeanContext
385       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
386       *       .beanMapPutReturnsOldValue()
387       *       .build();
388       *
389       *    BeanMap&lt;MyBean&gt; <jv>beanMap</jv> = <jv>context</jv>.createSession().toBeanMap(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
390       *    <jv>beanMap</jv>.put(<js>"foo"</js>, <js>"bar"</js>);
391       *    Object <jv>oldValue</jv> = <jv>beanMap</jv>.put(<js>"foo"</js>, <js>"baz"</js>);  <jc>// oldValue == "bar"</jc>
392       * </p>
393       *
394       * <ul class='seealso'>
395       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#beanMapPutReturnsOldValue()}
396       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#beanMapPutReturnsOldValue()}
397       * </ul>
398       *
399       * @return This object.
400       */
401      @FluentSetter
402      public Builder beanMapPutReturnsOldValue() {
403         bcBuilder.beanMapPutReturnsOldValue();
404         return this;
405      }
406
407      /**
408       * Minimum bean method visibility.
409       *
410       * <p>
411       * Only look for bean methods with the specified minimum visibility.
412       *
413       * <p>
414       * This affects which methods are detected as getters and setters on a bean class. Normally only <jk>public</jk> getters and setters are considered.
415       * Use this setting if you want to reduce the visibility requirement.
416       *
417       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
418       * <p class='bjava'>
419       *    <jc>// A bean with a protected getter.</jc>
420       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
421       *       <jk>public</jk> String getFoo() { <jk>return</jk> <js>"foo"</js>; }
422       *       <jk>protected</jk> String getBar() { <jk>return</jk> <js>"bar"</js>; }
423       *    }
424       *
425       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that looks for protected getters and setters.</jc>
426       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
427       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
428       *       .beanMethodVisibility(<jsf>PROTECTED</jsf>)
429       *       .build();
430       *
431       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"foo","bar":"bar"}</jc>
432       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
433       * </p>
434       *
435       * <ul class='notes'>
436       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Beanp @Beanp} annotation can also be used to expose a non-public method.
437       *    <li class='note'>The {@link BeanIgnore @BeanIgnore} annotation can also be used on a public bean getter/setter to ignore it as a bean property.
438       * </ul>
439       *
440       * <ul class='seealso'>
441       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#beanMethodVisibility()}
442       * </ul>
443       *
444       * @param value
445       *    The new value for this setting.
446       *    <br>The default is {@link Visibility#PUBLIC}
447       * @return This object.
448       */
449      @FluentSetter
450      public Builder beanMethodVisibility(Visibility value) {
451         bcBuilder.beanMethodVisibility(value);
452         return this;
453      }
454
455      /**
456       * Beans require no-arg constructors.
457       *
458       * <p>
459       * When enabled, a Java class must implement a default no-arg constructor to be considered a bean.
460       * Otherwise, the bean will be serialized as a string using the {@link Object#toString()} method.
461       *
462       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
463       * <p class='bjava'>
464       *    <jc>// A bean without a no-arg constructor.</jc>
465       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
466       *
467       *       <jc>// A property method.</jc>
468       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>;
469       *
470       *       <jc>// A no-arg constructor</jc>
471       *       <jk>public</jk> MyBean(String <jv>foo</jv>) {
472       *          <jk>this</jk>.<jf>foo</jf> = <jv>foo</jv>;
473       *       }
474       *
475       *       <ja>@Override</ja>
476       *       <jk>public</jk> String toString() {
477       *          <jk>return</jk> <js>"bar"</js>;
478       *       }
479       *    }
480       *
481       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that ignores beans without default constructors.</jc>
482       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
483       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
484       *       .beansRequireDefaultConstructor()
485       *       .build();
486       *
487       *    <jc>// Produces:  "bar"</jc>
488       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
489       * </p>
490       *
491       * <ul class='notes'>
492       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Bean @Bean} annotation can be used on a bean class to override this setting.
493       *    <li class='note'>The {@link BeanIgnore @BeanIgnore} annotation can also be used on a class to ignore it as a bean.
494       * </ul>
495       *
496       * <ul class='seealso'>
497       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#beansRequireDefaultConstructor()}
498       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#beansRequireDefaultConstructor()}
499       * </ul>
500       *
501       * @return This object.
502       */
503      @FluentSetter
504      public Builder beansRequireDefaultConstructor() {
505         bcBuilder.beansRequireDefaultConstructor();
506         return this;
507      }
508
509      /**
510       * Beans require Serializable interface.
511       *
512       * <p>
513       * When enabled, a Java class must implement the {@link Serializable} interface to be considered a bean.
514       * Otherwise, the bean will be serialized as a string using the {@link Object#toString()} method.
515       *
516       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
517       * <p class='bjava'>
518       *    <jc>// A bean without a Serializable interface.</jc>
519       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
520       *
521       *       <jc>// A property method.</jc>
522       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>;
523       *
524       *       <ja>@Override</ja>
525       *       <jk>public</jk> String toString() {
526       *          <jk>return</jk> <js>"bar"</js>;
527       *       }
528       *    }
529       *
530       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that ignores beans not implementing Serializable.</jc>
531       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
532       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
533       *       .beansRequireSerializable()
534       *       .build();
535       *
536       *    <jc>// Produces:  "bar"</jc>
537       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
538       * </p>
539       *
540       * <ul class='notes'>
541       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Bean @Bean} annotation can be used on a bean class to override this setting.
542       *    <li class='note'>The {@link BeanIgnore @BeanIgnore} annotation can also be used on a class to ignore it as a bean.
543       * </ul>
544       *
545       * <ul class='seealso'>
546       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#beansRequireSerializable()}
547       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#beansRequireSerializable()}
548       * </ul>
549       *
550       * @return This object.
551       */
552      @FluentSetter
553      public Builder beansRequireSerializable() {
554         bcBuilder.beansRequireSerializable();
555         return this;
556      }
557
558      /**
559       * Beans require setters for getters.
560       *
561       * <p>
562       * When enabled, ignore read-only properties (properties with getters but not setters).
563       *
564       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
565       * <p class='bjava'>
566       *    <jc>// A bean without a Serializable interface.</jc>
567       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
568       *
569       *       <jc>// A read/write property.</jc>
570       *       <jk>public</jk> String getFoo() { <jk>return</jk> <js>"foo"</js>; }
571       *       <jk>public void</jk> setFoo(String <jv>foo</jv>) { ... }
572       *
573       *       <jc>// A read-only property.</jc>
574       *       <jk>public</jk> String getBar() { <jk>return</jk> <js>"bar"</js>; }
575       *    }
576       *
577       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that ignores bean properties without setters.</jc>
578       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
579       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
580       *       .beansRequireSettersForGetters()
581       *       .build();
582       *
583       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"foo"}</jc>
584       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
585       * </p>
586       *
587       * <ul class='notes'>
588       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Beanp @Beanp} annotation can be used on the getter to override this setting.
589       *    <li class='note'>The {@link BeanIgnore @BeanIgnore} annotation can also be used on getters to ignore them as bean properties.
590       * </ul>
591       *
592       * <ul class='seealso'>
593       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#beansRequireSettersForGetters()}
594       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#beansRequireSettersForGetters()}
595       * </ul>
596       *
597       * @return This object.
598       */
599      @FluentSetter
600      public Builder beansRequireSettersForGetters() {
601         bcBuilder.beansRequireSettersForGetters();
602         return this;
603      }
604
605      /**
606       * Beans don't require at least one property.
607       *
608       * <p>
609       * When enabled, then a Java class doesn't need to contain at least 1 property to be considered a bean.
610       * Otherwise, the bean will be serialized as a string using the {@link Object#toString()} method.
611       *
612       * <p>
613       * The {@link Bean @Bean} annotation can be used on a class to override this setting when <jk>true</jk>.
614       *
615       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
616       * <p class='bjava'>
617       *    <jc>// A bean with no properties.</jc>
618       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
619       *    }
620       *
621       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that serializes beans even if they have zero properties.</jc>
622       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
623       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
624       *       .disableBeansRequireSomeProperties()
625       *       .build();
626       *
627       *    <jc>// Produces:  {}</jc>
628       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
629       * </p>
630       *
631       * <ul class='notes'>
632       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Bean @Bean} annotation can be used on the class to force it to be recognized as a bean class
633       *       even if it has no properties.
634       * </ul>
635       *
636       * <ul class='seealso'>
637       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#disableBeansRequireSomeProperties()}
638       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#disableBeansRequireSomeProperties()}
639       * </ul>
640       *
641       * @return This object.
642       */
643      @FluentSetter
644      public Builder disableBeansRequireSomeProperties() {
645         bcBuilder.disableBeansRequireSomeProperties();
646         return this;
647      }
648
649      /**
650       * Bean property includes.
651       *
652       * <p>
653       * Specifies the set and order of names of properties associated with the bean class.
654       *
655       * <p>
656       * For example, <c>beanProperties(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <js>"foo,bar"</js>)</c> means only serialize the <c>foo</c> and
657       * <c>bar</c> properties on the specified bean.  Likewise, parsing will ignore any bean properties not specified
658       * and either throw an exception or silently ignore them depending on whether {@link #ignoreUnknownBeanProperties()}
659       * has been called.
660       *
661       * <p>
662       * This value is entirely optional if you simply want to expose all the getters and public fields on
663       * a class as bean properties.  However, it's useful if you want certain getters to be ignored or you want the properties to be
664       * serialized in a particular order.  Note that on IBM JREs, the property order is the same as the order in the source code,
665       * whereas on Oracle JREs, the order is entirely random.
666       *
667       * <p>
668       * Setting applies to specified class and all subclasses.
669       *
670       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
671       * <p class='bjava'>
672       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
673       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
674       *       <jk>public</jk> String
675       *          <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"foo"</js>,
676       *          <jf>bar</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>,
677       *          <jf>baz</jf> = <js>"baz"</js>;
678       *    }
679       *
680       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that includes only the 'foo' and 'bar' properties on the MyBean class.</jc>
681       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
682       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
683       *       .beanProperties(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <js>"foo,bar"</js>)
684       *       .build();
685       *
686       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"foo","bar":"bar"}</jc>
687       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
688       * </p>
689       *
690       * <p>
691       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code:
692       * <p class='bjava'>
693       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>beanClass</jv>).properties(<jv>properties</jv>).build());
694       * </p>
695       *
696       * <ul class='seealso'>
697       *    <li class='jm'>{@link Bean#properties()}/{@link Bean#p()} - On an annotation on the bean class itself.
698       * </ul>
699       *
700       * @param beanClass The bean class.
701       * @param properties Comma-delimited list of property names.
702       * @return This object.
703       */
704      @FluentSetter
705      public Builder beanProperties(Class<?> beanClass, String properties) {
706         bcBuilder.beanProperties(beanClass, properties);
707         return this;
708      }
709
710      /**
711       * Bean property includes.
712       *
713       * <p>
714       * Specifies the set and order of names of properties associated with bean classes.
715       *
716       * <p>
717       * For example, <c>beanProperties(AMap.<jsm>of</jsm>(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"foo,bar"</js>))</c> means only serialize the <c>foo</c> and
718       * <c>bar</c> properties on the specified bean.  Likewise, parsing will ignore any bean properties not specified
719       * and either throw an exception or silently ignore them depending on whether {@link #ignoreUnknownBeanProperties()}
720       * has been called.
721       *
722       * <p>
723       * This value is entirely optional if you simply want to expose all the getters and public fields on
724       * a class as bean properties.  However, it's useful if you want certain getters to be ignored or you want the properties to be
725       * serialized in a particular order.  Note that on IBM JREs, the property order is the same as the order in the source code,
726       * whereas on Oracle JREs, the order is entirely random.
727       *
728       * <p>
729       * Setting applies to specified class and all subclasses.
730       *
731       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
732       * <p class='bjava'>
733       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
734       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
735       *       <jk>public</jk> String
736       *          <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"foo"</js>,
737       *          <jf>bar</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>,
738       *          <jf>baz</jf> = <js>"baz"</js>;
739       *    }
740       *
741       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that includes only the 'foo' and 'bar' properties on the MyBean class.</jc>
742       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
743       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
744       *       .beanProperties(AMap.<jsm>of</jsm>(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"foo,bar"</js>))
745       *       .build();
746       *
747       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"foo","bar":"bar"}</jc>
748       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
749       * </p>
750       *
751       * <p>
752       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code for each entry:
753       * <p class='bjava'>
754       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>key</jv>).properties(<jv>value</jv>.toString()).build());
755       * </p>
756       *
757       * <ul class='seealso'>
758       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#properties()} / {@link Bean#p()}- On an annotation on the bean class itself.
759       * </ul>
760       *
761       * @param values
762       *    The values to add to this builder.
763       *    <br>Keys are bean class names which can be a simple name, fully-qualified name, or <js>"*"</js> for all beans.
764       *    <br>Values are comma-delimited lists of property names.  Non-String objects are first converted to Strings.
765       * @return This object.
766       */
767      @FluentSetter
768      public Builder beanProperties(Map<String,Object> values) {
769         bcBuilder.beanProperties(values);
770         return this;
771      }
772
773      /**
774       * Bean property includes.
775       *
776       * <p>
777       * Specifies the set and order of names of properties associated with the bean class.
778       *
779       * <p>
780       * For example, <c>beanProperties(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"foo,bar"</js>)</c> means only serialize the <c>foo</c> and
781       * <c>bar</c> properties on the specified bean.  Likewise, parsing will ignore any bean properties not specified
782       * and either throw an exception or silently ignore them depending on whether {@link #ignoreUnknownBeanProperties()}
783       * has been called.
784       *
785       * <p>
786       * This value is entirely optional if you simply want to expose all the getters and public fields on
787       * a class as bean properties.  However, it's useful if you want certain getters to be ignored or you want the properties to be
788       * serialized in a particular order.  Note that on IBM JREs, the property order is the same as the order in the source code,
789       * whereas on Oracle JREs, the order is entirely random.
790       *
791       * <p>
792       * Setting applies to specified class and all subclasses.
793       *
794       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
795       * <p class='bjava'>
796       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
797       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
798       *       <jk>public</jk> String
799       *          <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"foo"</js>,
800       *          <jf>bar</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>,
801       *          <jf>baz</jf> = <js>"baz"</js>;
802       *    }
803       *
804       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that includes only the 'foo' and 'bar' properties on the MyBean class.</jc>
805       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
806       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
807       *       .beanProperties(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"foo,bar"</js>)
808       *       .build();
809       *
810       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"foo","bar":"bar"}</jc>
811       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
812       * </p>
813       *
814       * <p>
815       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code:
816       * <p class='bjava'>
817       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>beanClassName</jv>).properties(<jv>properties</jv>).build());
818       * </p>
819       *
820       * <ul class='seealso'>
821       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#properties()} / {@link Bean#p()} - On an annotation on the bean class itself.
822       * </ul>
823       *
824       * @param beanClassName
825       *    The bean class name.
826       *    <br>Can be a simple name, fully-qualified name, or <js>"*"</js> for all beans.
827       * @param properties Comma-delimited list of property names.
828       * @return This object.
829       */
830      @FluentSetter
831      public Builder beanProperties(String beanClassName, String properties) {
832         bcBuilder.beanProperties(beanClassName, properties);
833         return this;
834      }

836      /**
837       * Bean property excludes.
838       *
839       * <p>
840       * Specifies to exclude the specified list of properties for the specified bean class.
841       *
842       * <p>
843       * Same as {@link #beanProperties(Class, String)} except you specify a list of bean property names that you want to exclude from
844       * serialization.
845       *
846       * <p>
847       * Setting applies to specified class and all subclasses.
848       *
849       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
850       * <p class='bjava'>
851       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
852       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
853       *       <jk>public</jk> String
854       *          <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"foo"</js>,
855       *          <jf>bar</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>,
856       *          <jf>baz</jf> = <js>"baz"</js>;
857       *    }
858       *
859       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that excludes the "bar" and "baz" properties on the MyBean class.</jc>
860       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
861       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
862       *       .beanPropertiesExcludes(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
863       *       .build();
864       *
865       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"foo"}</jc>
866       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
867       * </p>
868       *
869       * <p>
870       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code:
871       * <p class='bjava'>
872       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>beanClass</jv>).excludeProperties(<jv>properties</jv>).build());
873       * </p>
874       *
875       * <ul class='seealso'>
876       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#excludeProperties()} / {@link Bean#xp()}
877       * </ul>
878       *
879       * @param beanClass The bean class.
880       * @param properties Comma-delimited list of property names.
881       * @return This object.
882       */
883      @FluentSetter
884      public Builder beanPropertiesExcludes(Class<?> beanClass, String properties) {
885         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesExcludes(beanClass, properties);
886         return this;
887      }

889      /**
890       * Bean property excludes.
891       *
892       * <p>
893       * Specifies to exclude the specified list of properties for the specified bean classes.
894       *
895       * <p>
896       * Same as {@link #beanProperties(Map)} except you specify a list of bean property names that you want to exclude from
897       * serialization.
898       *
899       * <p>
900       * Setting applies to specified class and all subclasses.
901       *
902       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
903       * <p class='bjava'>
904       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
905       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
906       *       <jk>public</jk> String
907       *          <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"foo"</js>,
908       *          <jf>bar</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>,
909       *          <jf>baz</jf> = <js>"baz"</js>;
910       *    }
911       *
912       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that excludes the "bar" and "baz" properties on the MyBean class.</jc>
913       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
914       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
915       *       .beanPropertiesExcludes(AMap.of(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>))
916       *       .build();
917       *
918       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"foo"}</jc>
919       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
920       * </p>
921       *
922       * <p>
923       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code for each entry:
924       * <p class='bjava'>
925       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>key</jv>).excludeProperties(<jv>value</jv>.toString()).build());
926       * </p>
927       *
928       * <ul class='seealso'>
929       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#excludeProperties()} / {@link Bean#xp()}
930       * </ul>
931       *
932       * @param values
933       *    The values to add to this builder.
934       *    <br>Keys are bean class names which can be a simple name, fully-qualified name, or <js>"*"</js> for all beans.
935       *    <br>Values are comma-delimited lists of property names.  Non-String objects are first converted to Strings.
936       * @return This object.
937       */
938      @FluentSetter
939      public Builder beanPropertiesExcludes(Map<String,Object> values) {
940         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesExcludes(values);
941         return this;
942      }

944      /**
945       * Bean property excludes.
946       *
947       * <p>
948       * Specifies to exclude the specified list of properties for the specified bean class.
949       *
950       * <p>
951       * Same as {@link #beanPropertiesExcludes(String, String)} except you specify a list of bean property names that you want to exclude from
952       * serialization.
953       *

959       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
960       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
961       *       <jk>public</jk> String
962       *          <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"foo"</js>,
963       *          <jf>bar</jf> = <js>"bar"</js>,
964       *          <jf>baz</jf> = <js>"baz"</js>;
965       *    }
966       *
967       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that excludes the "bar" and "baz" properties on the MyBean class.</jc>
968       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
969       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
970       *       .beanPropertiesExcludes(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
971       *       .build();
972       *
973       *    <jc>// Produces:  {"foo":"foo"}</jc>
974       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
975       * </p>
976       *
977       * <p>
978       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code:
979       * <p class='bjava'>
980       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>beanClassName</jv>).excludeProperties(<jv>properties</jv>).build());
981       * </p>
982       *
983       * <ul class='seealso'>
984       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#excludeProperties()} / {@link Bean#xp()}
985       * </ul>
986       *
987       * @param beanClassName
988       *    The bean class name.
989       *    <br>Can be a simple name, fully-qualified name, or <js>"*"</js> for all bean classes.
990       * @param properties Comma-delimited list of property names.
991       * @return This object.
992       */
993      @FluentSetter
994      public Builder beanPropertiesExcludes(String beanClassName, String properties) {
995         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesExcludes(beanClassName, properties);
996         return this;
997      }
998
999      /**
1000       * Read-only bean properties.
1001       *
1002       * <p>
1003       * Specifies one or more properties on a bean that are read-only despite having valid getters.
1004       * Serializers will serialize such properties as usual, but parsers will silently ignore them.
1005       * Note that this is different from the {@link #beanProperties(Class,String) beanProperties}/{@link #beanPropertiesExcludes(Class,String) beanPropertiesExcludes} settings which include or exclude properties
1006       * for both serializers and parsers.
1007       *
1008       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1009       * <p class='bjava'>
1010       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
1011       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1012       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf>, <jf>bar</jf>, <jf>baz</jf>;
1013       *    }
1014       *
1015       *    <jc>// Create a serializer with read-only property settings.</jc>
1016       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1017       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1018       *       .beanPropertiesReadOnly(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
1019       *       .build();
1020       *
1021       *    <jc>// All 3 properties will be serialized.</jc>
1022       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
1023       *
1024       *    <jc>// Create a parser with read-only property settings.</jc>
1025       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1026       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1027       *       .beanPropertiesReadOnly(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
1028       *       .ignoreUnknownBeanProperties()
1029       *       .build();
1030       *
1031       *    <jc>// Parser ignores bar and baz properties.</jc>
1032       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'foo',bar:'bar',baz:'baz'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1033       * </p>
1034       *
1035       * <p>
1036       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code:
1037       * <p class='bjava'>
1038       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>beanClass</jv>).readOnlyProperties(<jv>properties</jv>).build());
1039       * </p>
1040       *
1041       * <ul class='seealso'>
1042       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#readOnlyProperties()} / {@link Bean#ro()}
1043       * </ul>
1044       *
1045       * @param beanClass The bean class.
1046       * @param properties Comma-delimited list of property names.
1047       * @return This object.
1048       */
1049      @FluentSetter
1050      public Builder beanPropertiesReadOnly(Class<?> beanClass, String properties) {
1051         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesReadOnly(beanClass, properties);
1052         return this;
1053      }
1054
1055      /**
1056       * Read-only bean properties.
1057       *
1058       * <p>
1059       * Specifies one or more properties on beans that are read-only despite having valid getters.
1060       * Serializers will serialize such properties as usual, but parsers will silently ignore them.
1061       * Note that this is different from the {@link #beanProperties(Class,String) beanProperties}/{@link #beanPropertiesExcludes(Class,String) beanPropertiesExcludes} settings which include or exclude properties
1062       * for both serializers and parsers.
1063       *
1064       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1065       * <p class='bjava'>
1066       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
1067       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1068       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf>, <jf>bar</jf>, <jf>baz</jf>;
1069       *    }
1070       *
1071       *    <jc>// Create a serializer with read-only property settings.</jc>
1072       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1073       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1074       *       .beanPropertiesReadOnly(AMap.<jsm>of</jsm>(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>))
1075       *       .build();
1076       *
1077       *    <jc>// All 3 properties will be serialized.</jc>
1078       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
1079       *
1080       *    <jc>// Create a parser with read-only property settings.</jc>
1081       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1082       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1083       *       .beanPropertiesReadOnly(AMap.<jsm>of</jsm>(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>))
1084       *       .ignoreUnknownBeanProperties()
1085       *       .build();
1086       *
1087       *    <jc>// Parser ignores bar and baz properties.</jc>
1088       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'foo',bar:'bar',baz:'baz'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1089       * </p>
1090       *
1091       * <p>
1092       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code for each entry:
1093       * <p class='bjava'>
1094       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>key</jv>).readOnlyProperties(<jv>value</jv>.toString()).build());
1095       * </p>
1096       *
1097       * <ul class='seealso'>
1098       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#readOnlyProperties()} / {@link Bean#ro()}
1099       * </ul>
1100       *
1101       * @param values
1102       *    The values to add to this builder.
1103       *    <br>Keys are bean class names which can be a simple name, fully-qualified name, or <js>"*"</js> for all beans.
1104       *    <br>Values are comma-delimited lists of property names.  Non-String objects are first converted to Strings.
1105       * @return This object.
1106       */
1107      @FluentSetter
1108      public Builder beanPropertiesReadOnly(Map<String,Object> values) {
1109         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesReadOnly(values);
1110         return this;
1111      }

1113      /**
1114       * Read-only bean properties.
1115       *
1116       * <p>
1117       * Specifies one or more properties on a bean that are read-only despite having valid getters.
1118       * Serializers will serialize such properties as usual, but parsers will silently ignore them.
1119       * Note that this is different from the {@link #beanProperties(Class,String) beanProperties}/{@link #beanPropertiesExcludes(Class,String) beanPropertiesExcludes} settings which include or exclude properties
1120       * for both serializers and parsers.
1121       *
1122       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1123       * <p class='bjava'>
1124       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
1125       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1126       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf>, <jf>bar</jf>, <jf>baz</jf>;
1127       *    }
1128       *
1129       *    <jc>// Create a serializer with read-only property settings.</jc>
1130       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1131       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1132       *       .beanPropertiesReadOnly(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
1133       *       .build();
1134       *
1135       *    <jc>// All 3 properties will be serialized.</jc>
1136       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
1137       *
1138       *    <jc>// Create a parser with read-only property settings.</jc>
1139       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1140       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1141       *       .beanPropertiesReadOnly(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
1142       *       .ignoreUnknownBeanProperties()
1143       *       .build();
1144       *
1145       *    <jc>// Parser ignores bar and baz properties.</jc>
1146       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'foo',bar:'bar',baz:'baz'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1147       * </p>
1148       *
1149       * <p>
1150       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code:
1151       * <p class='bjava'>
1152       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>beanClassName</jv>).readOnlyProperties(<jv>properties</jv>).build());
1153       * </p>
1154       *
1155       * <ul class='seealso'>
1156       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#readOnlyProperties()} / {@link Bean#ro()}
1157       * </ul>
1158       *
1159       * @param beanClassName
1160       *    The bean class name.
1161       *    <br>Can be a simple name, fully-qualified name, or <js>"*"</js> for all bean classes.
1162       * @param properties Comma-delimited list of property names.
1163       * @return This object.
1164       */
1165      @FluentSetter
1166      public Builder beanPropertiesReadOnly(String beanClassName, String properties) {
1167         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesReadOnly(beanClassName, properties);
1168         return this;
1169      }
1170
1171      /**
1172       * Write-only bean properties.
1173       *
1174       * <p>
1175       * Specifies one or more properties on a bean that are write-only despite having valid setters.
1176       * Parsers will parse such properties as usual, but serializers will silently ignore them.
1177       * Note that this is different from the {@link #beanProperties(Class,String) beanProperties}/{@link #beanPropertiesExcludes(Class,String) beanPropertiesExcludes} settings which include or exclude properties
1178       * for both serializers and parsers.
1179       *
1180       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1181       * <p class='bjava'>
1182       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
1183       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1184       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf>, <jf>bar</jf>, <jf>baz</jf>;
1185       *    }
1186       *
1187       *    <jc>// Create a serializer with write-only property settings.</jc>
1188       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1189       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1190       *       .beanPropertiesWriteOnly(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
1191       *       .build();
1192       *
1193       *    <jc>// Only foo will be serialized.</jc>
1194       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
1195       *
1196       *    <jc>// Create a parser with write-only property settings.</jc>
1197       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1198       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1199       *       .beanPropertiesWriteOnly(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
1200       *       .build();
1201       *
1202       *    <jc>// Parser parses all 3 properties.</jc>
1203       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'foo',bar:'bar',baz:'baz'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1204       * </p>
1205       *
1206       * <p>
1207       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code:
1208       * <p class='bjava'>
1209       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>beanClass</jv>).writeOnlyProperties(<jv>properties</jv>).build());
1210       * </p>
1211       *
1212       * <ul class='seealso'>
1213       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#writeOnlyProperties()} / {@link Bean#wo()}
1214       * </ul>
1215       *
1216       * @param beanClass The bean class.
1217       * @param properties Comma-delimited list of property names.
1218       * @return This object.
1219       */
1220      @FluentSetter
1221      public Builder beanPropertiesWriteOnly(Class<?> beanClass, String properties) {
1222         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesWriteOnly(beanClass, properties);
1223         return this;
1224      }
1225
1226      /**
1227       * Write-only bean properties.
1228       *
1229       * <p>
1230       * Specifies one or more properties on a bean that are write-only despite having valid setters.
1231       * Parsers will parse such properties as usual, but serializers will silently ignore them.
1232       * Note that this is different from the {@link #beanProperties(Class,String) beanProperties}/{@link #beanPropertiesExcludes(Class,String) beanPropertiesExcludes} settings which include or exclude properties
1233       * for both serializers and parsers.
1234       *
1235       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1236       * <p class='bjava'>
1237       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
1238       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1239       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf>, <jf>bar</jf>, <jf>baz</jf>;
1240       *    }
1241       *
1242       *    <jc>// Create a serializer with write-only property settings.</jc>
1243       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1244       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1245       *       .beanPropertiesWriteOnly(AMap.<jsm>of</jsm>(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>))
1246       *       .build();
1247       *
1248       *    <jc>// Only foo will be serialized.</jc>
1249       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
1250       *
1251       *    <jc>// Create a parser with write-only property settings.</jc>
1252       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1253       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1254       *       .beanPropertiesWriteOnly(AMap.<jsm>of</jsm>(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>))
1255       *       .build();
1256       *
1257       *    <jc>// Parser parses all 3 properties.</jc>
1258       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'foo',bar:'bar',baz:'baz'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1259       * </p>
1260       *
1261       * <p>
1262       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code for each entry:
1263       * <p class='bjava'>
1264       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>key</jv>).writeOnlyProperties(<jv>value</jv>.toString()).build());
1265       * </p>
1266       *
1267       * <ul class='seealso'>
1268       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#writeOnlyProperties()} / {@link Bean#wo()}
1269       * </ul>
1270       *
1271       * @param values
1272       *    The values to add to this builder.
1273       *    <br>Keys are bean class names which can be a simple name, fully-qualified name, or <js>"*"</js> for all beans.
1274       *    <br>Values are comma-delimited lists of property names.  Non-String objects are first converted to Strings.
1275       * @return This object.
1276       */
1277      @FluentSetter
1278      public Builder beanPropertiesWriteOnly(Map<String,Object> values) {
1279         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesWriteOnly(values);
1280         return this;
1281      }
1282
1283      /**
1284       * Write-only bean properties.
1285       *
1286       * <p>
1287       * Specifies one or more properties on a bean that are write-only despite having valid setters.
1288       * Parsers will parse such properties as usual, but serializers will silently ignore them.
1289       * Note that this is different from the {@link #beanProperties(Class,String) beanProperties}/{@link #beanPropertiesExcludes(Class,String) beanPropertiesExcludes} settings which include or exclude properties
1290       * for both serializers and parsers.
1291       *
1292       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1293       * <p class='bjava'>
1294       *    <jc>// A bean with 3 properties.</jc>
1295       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1296       *       <jk>public</jk> String <jf>foo</jf>, <jf>bar</jf>, <jf>baz</jf>;
1297       *    }
1298       *
1299       *    <jc>// Create a serializer with write-only property settings.</jc>
1300       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1301       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1302       *       .beanPropertiesWriteOnly(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
1303       *       .build();
1304       *
1305       *    <jc>// Only foo will be serialized.</jc>
1306       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
1307       *
1308       *    <jc>// Create a parser with write-only property settings.</jc>
1309       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1310       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1311       *       .beanPropertiesWriteOnly(<js>"MyBean"</js>, <js>"bar,baz"</js>)
1312       *       .build();
1313       *
1314       *    <jc>// Parser parses all 3 properties.</jc>
1315       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'foo',bar:'bar',baz:'baz'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1316       * </p>
1317       *
1318       * <p>
1319       * This method is functionally equivalent to the following code:
1320       * <p class='bjava'>
1321       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(BeanAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>beanClassName</jv>).writeOnlyProperties(<jv>properties</jv>).build());
1322       * </p>
1323       *
1324       * <ul class='seealso'>
1325       *    <li class='jma'>{@link Bean#writeOnlyProperties()} / {@link Bean#wo()}
1326       * </ul>
1327       *
1328       * @param beanClassName
1329       *    The bean class name.
1330       *    <br>Can be a simple name, fully-qualified name, or <js>"*"</js> for all bean classes.
1331       * @param properties Comma-delimited list of property names.
1332       * @return This object.
1333       */
1334      @FluentSetter
1335      public Builder beanPropertiesWriteOnly(String beanClassName, String properties) {
1336         bcBuilder.beanPropertiesWriteOnly(beanClassName, properties);
1337         return this;
1338      }
1339
1340      /**
1341       * Bean dictionary.
1342       *
1343       * <p>
1344       * The list of classes that make up the bean dictionary in this bean context.
1345       *
1346       * <p>
1347       * Values are prepended to the list so that later calls can override classes of earlier calls.
1348       *
1349       * <p>
1350       * A dictionary is a name/class mapping used to find class types during parsing when they cannot be inferred
1351       * through reflection.  The names are defined through the {@link Bean#typeName() @Bean(typeName)} annotation defined
1352       * on the bean class.  For example, if a class <c>Foo</c> has a type-name of <js>"myfoo"</js>, then it would end up
1353       * serialized as <js>"{_type:'myfoo',...}"</js> in JSON
1354       * or <js>"&lt;myfoo&gt;...&lt;/myfoo&gt;"</js> in XML.
1355       *
1356       * <p>
1357       * This setting tells the parsers which classes to look for when resolving <js>"_type"</js> attributes.
1358       *
1359       * <p>
1360       * Values can consist of any of the following types:
1361       * <ul>
1362       *    <li>Any bean class that specifies a value for {@link Bean#typeName() @Bean(typeName)}.
1363       *    <li>Any subclass of {@link BeanDictionaryList} containing a collection of bean classes with type name annotations.
1364       *    <li>Any subclass of {@link BeanDictionaryMap} containing a mapping of type names to classes without type name annotations.
1365       *    <li>Any array or collection of the objects above.
1366       * </ul>
1367       *
1368       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1369       * <p class='bjava'>
1370       *    <jc>// POJOs with @Bean(name) annotations.</jc>
1371       *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(typeName=<js>"foo"</js>)
1372       *    <jk>public class</jk> Foo {...}
1373       *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(typeName=<js>"bar"</js>)
1374       *    <jk>public class</jk> Bar {...}
1375       *
1376       *    <jc>// Create a parser and tell it which classes to try to resolve.</jc>
1377       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1378       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1379       *       .dictionary(Foo.<jk>class</jk>, Bar.<jk>class</jk>)
1380       *       .addBeanTypes()
1381       *       .build();
1382       *
1383       *    <jc>// A bean with a field with an indeterminate type.</jc>
1384       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1385       *       <jk>public</jk> Object <jf>mySimpleField</jf>;
1386       *    }
1387       *
1388       *    <jc>// Parse bean.</jc>
1389       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{mySimpleField:{_type:'foo',...}}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1390       * </p>
1391       *
1392       * <p>
1393       * Another option is to use the {@link Bean#dictionary()} annotation on the POJO class itself:
1394       *
1395       * <p class='bjava'>
1396       *    <jc>// Instead of by parser, define a bean dictionary on a class through an annotation.</jc>
1397       *    <jc>// This applies to all properties on this class and all subclasses.</jc>
1398       *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(dictionary={Foo.<jk>class</jk>,Bar.<jk>class</jk>})
1399       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1400       *       <jk>public</jk> Object <jf>mySimpleField</jf>;  <jc>// May contain Foo or Bar object.</jc>
1401       *       <jk>public</jk> Map&lt;String,Object&gt; <jf>myMapField</jf>;  <jc>// May contain Foo or Bar objects.</jc>
1402       *    }
1403       * </p>
1404       *
1405       * <p>
1406       *    A typical usage is to allow for HTML documents to be parsed back into HTML beans:
1407       * <p class='bjava'>
1408       *    <jc>// Use the predefined HTML5 bean dictionary which is a BeanDictionaryList.</jc>
1409       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = HtmlParser
1410       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1411       *       .dictionary(HtmlBeanDictionary.<jk>class</jk>)
1412       *       .build();
1413       *
1414       *    <jc>// Parse an HTML body into HTML beans.</jc>
1415       *    Body <jv>body</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"&lt;body&gt;&lt;ul&gt;&lt;li&gt;foo&lt;/li&gt;&lt;li&gt;bar&lt;/li&gt;&lt;/ul&gt;"</js>, Body.<jk>class</jk>);
1416       * </p>
1417       *
1418       * <ul class='seealso'>
1419       *    <li class='ja'>{@link Bean#dictionary()}
1420       *    <li class='ja'>{@link Beanp#dictionary()}
1421       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#dictionary()}
1422       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#dictionary_replace()}
1423       * </ul>
1424       *
1425       * @param values
1426       *    The values to add to this setting.
1427       * @return This object.
1428       */
1429      @FluentSetter
1430      public Builder beanDictionary(Class<?>...values) {
1431         bcBuilder.beanDictionary(values);
1432         return this;
1433      }
1434
1435      /**
1436       * Bean dictionary.
1437       *
1438       * <p>
1439       * This is identical to {@link #beanDictionary(Class...)}, but specifies a dictionary within the context of
1440       * a single class as opposed to globally.
1441       *
1442       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1443       * <p class='bjava'>
1444       *    <jc>// POJOs with @Bean(name) annotations.</jc>
1445       *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(typeName=<js>"foo"</js>)
1446       *    <jk>public class</jk> Foo {...}
1447       *    <ja>@Bean</ja>(typeName=<js>"bar"</js>)
1448       *    <jk>public class</jk> Bar {...}
1449       *
1450       *    <jc>// A bean with a field with an indeterminate type.</jc>
1451       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1452       *       <jk>public</jk> Object <jf>mySimpleField</jf>;
1453       *    }
1454       *
1455       *    <jc>// Create a parser and tell it which classes to try to resolve.</jc>
1456       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1457       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1458       *       .dictionaryOn(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, Foo.<jk>class</jk>, Bar.<jk>class</jk>)
1459       *       .build();
1460       *
1461       *    <jc>// Parse bean.</jc>
1462       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{mySimpleField:{_type:'foo',...}}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1463       * </p>
1464       *
1465       * <p>
1466       * This is functionally equivalent to the {@link Bean#dictionary()} annotation.
1467       *
1468       * <ul class='seealso'>
1469       *    <li class='ja'>{@link Bean#dictionary()}
1470       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#beanDictionary(Class...)}
1471       * </ul>
1472       *
1473       * @param on The class that the dictionary values apply to.
1474       * @param values
1475       *    The new values for this setting.
1476       * @return This object.
1477       */
1478      @FluentSetter
1479      public Builder dictionaryOn(Class<?> on, Class<?>...values) {
1480         bcBuilder.dictionaryOn(on, values);
1481         return this;
1482      }
1483
1484      /**
1485       * POJO example.
1486       *
1487       * <p>
1488       * Specifies an example of the specified class.
1489       *
1490       * <p>
1491       * Examples are used in cases such as POJO examples in Swagger documents.
1492       *
1493       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1494       * <p class='bjava'>
1495       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that excludes the 'foo' and 'bar' properties on the MyBean class.</jc>
1496       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1497       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1498       *       .example(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <jk>new</jk> MyBean().setFoo(<js>"foo"</js>).setBar(123))
1499       *       .build();
1500       * </p>
1501       *
1502       * <p>
1503       * This is a shorthand method for the following code:
1504       * <p class='bjava'>
1505       *       <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(MarshalledAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>pojoClass</jv>).example(Json5.<jsf>DEFAULT</jsf>.toString(<jv>object</jv>)).build())
1506       * </p>
1507       *
1508       * <ul class='notes'>
1509       *    <li class='note'>Using this method assumes the serialized form of the object is the same as that produced
1510       *       by the default serializer.  This may not be true based on settings or swaps on the constructed serializer.
1511       * </ul>
1512       *
1513       * <p>
1514       * POJO examples can also be defined on classes via the following:
1515       * <ul class='spaced-list'>
1516       *    <li>The {@link Marshalled#example()} annotation on the class itself.
1517       *    <li>A static field annotated with {@link Example @Example}.
1518       *    <li>A static method annotated with {@link Example @Example} with zero arguments or one {@link BeanSession} argument.
1519       *    <li>A static method with name <c>example</c> with no arguments or one {@link BeanSession} argument.
1520       * </ul>
1521       *
1522       * @param <T> The POJO class.
1523       * @param pojoClass The POJO class.
1524       * @param o
1525       *    An instance of the POJO class used for examples.
1526       * @return This object.
1527       */
1528      @FluentSetter
1529      public <T> Builder example(Class<T> pojoClass, T o) {
1530         bcBuilder.example(pojoClass, o);
1531         return this;
1532      }
1533
1534      /**
1535       * POJO example.
1536       *
1537       * <p>
1538       * Specifies an example in JSON of the specified class.
1539       *
1540       * <p>
1541       * Examples are used in cases such as POJO examples in Swagger documents.
1542       *
1543       * <p>
1544       * Setting applies to specified class and all subclasses.
1545       *
1546       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1547       * <p class='bjava'>
1548       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that excludes the 'foo' and 'bar' properties on the MyBean class.</jc>
1549       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1550       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1551       *       .example(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>, <js>"{foo:'bar'}"</js>)
1552       *       .build();
1553       * </p>
1554       *
1555       * <p>
1556       * This is a shorthand method for the following code:
1557       * <p class='bjava'>
1558       *    <jv>builder</jv>.annotations(MarshalledAnnotation.<jsm>create</jsm>(<jv>pojoClass</jv>).example(<jv>json</jv>).build())
1559       * </p>
1560       *
1561       * <p>
1562       * POJO examples can also be defined on classes via the following:
1563       * <ul class='spaced-list'>
1564       *    <li>A static field annotated with {@link Example @Example}.
1565       *    <li>A static method annotated with {@link Example @Example} with zero arguments or one {@link BeanSession} argument.
1566       *    <li>A static method with name <c>example</c> with no arguments or one {@link BeanSession} argument.
1567       * </ul>
1568       *
1569       * <ul class='seealso'>
1570       *    <li class='ja'>{@link Marshalled#example()}
1571       * </ul>
1572       *
1573       * @param <T> The POJO class type.
1574       * @param pojoClass The POJO class.
1575       * @param json The JSON 5 representation of the example.
1576       * @return This object.
1577       */
1578      @FluentSetter
1579      public <T> Builder example(Class<T> pojoClass, String json) {
1580         bcBuilder.example(pojoClass, json);
1581         return this;
1582      }
1583
1584      /**
1585       * Find fluent setters.
1586       *
1587       * <p>
1588       * When enabled, fluent setters are detected on beans during parsing.
1589       *
1590       * <p>
1591       * Fluent setters must have the following attributes:
1592       * <ul>
1593       *    <li>Public.
1594       *    <li>Not static.
1595       *    <li>Take in one parameter.
1596       *    <li>Return the bean itself.
1597       * </ul>
1598       *
1599       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1600       * <p class='bjava'>
1601       *    <jc>// A bean with a fluent setter.</jc>
1602       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1603       *       <jk>public</jk> MyBean foo(String <jv>value</jv>) {...}
1604       *    }
1605       *
1606       *    <jc>// Create a parser that finds fluent setters.</jc>
1607       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1608       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1609       *       .findFluentSetters()
1610       *       .build();
1611       *
1612       *    <jc>// Parse into bean using fluent setter.</jc>
1613       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'bar'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1614       * </p>
1615       *
1616       * <ul class='notes'>
1617       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Beanp @Beanp} annotation can also be used on methods to individually identify them as fluent setters.
1618       *    <li class='note'>The {@link Bean#findFluentSetters() @Bean.fluentSetters()} annotation can also be used on classes to specify to look for fluent setters.
1619       * </ul>
1620       *
1621       * <ul class='seealso'>
1622       *    <li class='ja'>{@link Bean#findFluentSetters()}
1623       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#findFluentSetters()}
1624       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#findFluentSetters()}
1625       * </ul>
1626       *
1627       * @return This object.
1628       */
1629      @FluentSetter
1630      public Builder findFluentSetters() {
1631         bcBuilder.findFluentSetters();
1632         return this;
1633      }
1634
1635      /**
1636       * Find fluent setters.
1637       *
1638       * <p>
1639       * Identical to {@link #findFluentSetters()} but enables it on a specific class only.
1640       *
1641       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1642       * <p class='bjava'>
1643       *    <jc>// A bean with a fluent setter.</jc>
1644       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1645       *       <jk>public</jk> MyBean foo(String <jv>value</jv>) {...}
1646       *    }
1647       *
1648       *    <jc>// Create a parser that finds fluent setters.</jc>
1649       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1650       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1651       *       .findFluentSetters(MyBean.<jk>class</jk>)
1652       *       .build();
1653       *
1654       *    <jc>// Parse into bean using fluent setter.</jc>
1655       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'bar'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1656       * </p>
1657       *
1658       * <ul class='notes'>
1659       *    <li class='note'>This method is functionally equivalent to using the {@link Bean#findFluentSetters()} annotation.
1660       * </ul>
1661       *
1662       * <ul class='seealso'>
1663       *    <li class='ja'>{@link Bean#findFluentSetters()}
1664       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#findFluentSetters()}
1665       * </ul>
1666       *
1667       * @param on The class that this applies to.
1668       * @return This object.
1669       */
1670      @FluentSetter
1671      public Builder findFluentSetters(Class<?> on) {
1672         bcBuilder.findFluentSetters(on);
1673         return this;
1674      }
1675
1676      /**
1677       * Ignore invocation errors on getters.
1678       *
1679       * <p>
1680       * When enabled, errors thrown when calling bean getter methods will silently be ignored.
1681       * Otherwise, a {@code BeanRuntimeException} is thrown.
1682       *
1683       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1684       * <p class='bjava'>
1685       *    <jc>// A bean with a property that throws an exception.</jc>
1686       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1687       *       <jk>public</jk> String getFoo() {
1688       *          <jk>throw new</jk> RuntimeException(<js>"foo"</js>);
1689       *       }
1690       *    }
1691       *
1692       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that ignores bean getter exceptions.</jc>
1693       *    WriterSerializer <jv>serializer</jv> = JsonSerializer
1694       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1695       *       .ingoreInvocationExceptionsOnGetters()
1696       *       .build();
1697       *
1698       *    <jc>// Exception is ignored.</jc>
1699       *    String <jv>json</jv> = <jv>serializer</jv>.serialize(<jk>new</jk> MyBean());
1700       * </p>
1701       *
1702       * <ul class='seealso'>
1703       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnGetters()}
1704       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnGetters()}
1705       * </ul>
1706       *
1707       * @return This object.
1708       */
1709      @FluentSetter
1710      public Builder ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnGetters() {
1711         bcBuilder.ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnGetters();
1712         return this;
1713      }
1714
1715      /**
1716       * Ignore invocation errors on setters.
1717       *
1718       * <p>
1719       * When enabled, errors thrown when calling bean setter methods will silently be ignored.
1720       * Otherwise, a {@code BeanRuntimeException} is thrown.
1721       *
1722       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1723       * <p class='bjava'>
1724       *    <jc>// A bean with a property that throws an exception.</jc>
1725       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1726       *       <jk>public void</jk> setFoo(String <jv>foo</jv>) {
1727       *          <jk>throw new</jk> RuntimeException(<js>"foo"</js>);
1728       *       }
1729       *    }
1730       *
1731       *    <jc>// Create a parser that ignores bean setter exceptions.</jc>
1732       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1733       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1734       *       .ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnSetters()
1735       *       .build();
1736       *
1737       *    <jc>// Exception is ignored.</jc>
1738       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'bar'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1739       * </p>
1740       *
1741       * <ul class='seealso'>
1742       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnSetters()}
1743       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnSetters()}
1744       * </ul>
1745       *
1746       * @return This object.
1747       */
1748      @FluentSetter
1749      public Builder ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnSetters() {
1750         bcBuilder.ignoreInvocationExceptionsOnSetters();
1751         return this;
1752      }
1753
1754      /**
1755       * Don't silently ignore missing setters.
1756       *
1757       * <p>
1758       * When enabled, trying to set a value on a bean property without a setter will throw a {@link BeanRuntimeException}.
1759       * Otherwise, it will be silently ignored.
1760       *
1761       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1762       * <p class='bjava'>
1763       *    <jc>// A bean with a property with a getter but not a setter.</jc>
1764       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1765       *       <jk>public void</jk> getFoo() {
1766       *          <jk>return</jk> <js>"foo"</js>;
1767       *       }
1768       *    }
1769       *
1770       *    <jc>// Create a parser that throws an exception if a setter is not found but a getter is.</jc>
1771       *    ReaderParser <jv>parser</jv> = JsonParser
1772       *       .<jsm>create</jsm>()
1773       *       .disableIgnoreMissingSetters()
1774       *       .build();
1775       *
1776       *    <jc>// Throws a ParseException.</jc>
1777       *    MyBean <jv>bean</jv> = <jv>parser</jv>.parse(<js>"{foo:'bar'}"</js>, MyBean.<jk>class</jk>);
1778       * </p>
1779       *
1780       * <ul class='notes'>
1781       *    <li class='note'>The {@link BeanIgnore @BeanIgnore} annotation can also be used on getters and fields to ignore them.
1782       * </ul>
1783       *
1784       * <ul class='seealso'>
1785       *    <li class='ja'>{@link BeanConfig#disableIgnoreMissingSetters()}
1786       *    <li class='jm'>{@link BeanContext.Builder#disableIgnoreMissingSetters()}
1787       * </ul>
1788       *
1789       * @return This object.
1790       */
1791      @FluentSetter
1792      public Builder disableIgnoreMissingSetters() {
1793         bcBuilder.disableIgnoreMissingSetters();
1794         return this;
1795      }
1796
1797      /**
1798       * Don't ignore transient fields.
1799       *
1800       * <p>
1801       * When enabled, methods and fields marked as <jk>transient</jk> will not be ignored as bean properties.
1802       *
1803       * <h5 class='section'>Example:</h5>
1804       * <p class='bjava'>
1805       *    <jc>// A bean with a transient field.</jc>
1806       *    <jk>public class</jk> MyBean {
1807       *       <jk>public transient</jk> String <jf>foo</jf> = <js>"foo"</js>;
1808       *    }
1809       *
1810       *    <jc>// Create a serializer that doesn't ignore transient fields.</jc>
